programme.title: CYCLE AROUND JAPAN
programme.sub-title: CYCLE AROUND TAIWAN - Into the Future, Together

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Magical Japanese
programme.desc: This episode focuses on words related to shio, or salt. Salt played an important role in the development of Japan's food culture and religion, and it continues to add flavor to many Japanese expressions.

programme.title: The Seasons of Yamato
programme.sub-title: Light Snow (Shousetsu) Whispers of Water / The 24 Solar Terms
programme.desc: As autumn deepens and winter approaches, we visit the Kasugayama Primeval Forest. Colorful autumn maple leaves float on the water's surface. Falling leaves and clear light. Stone Buddhas make you feel the quiet flow of time. *According to the 24 Solar Terms of Reiwa 6 (2024), Shousetsu is from November 22 to December 7.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.desc: In the Edo period, childbirth was a community affair, with the mother-to-be attended by a midwife and the women in her life. It was also characterized by unique customs and superstitions. *"The Birth of the First Child" sheet 7 of the series "Marriage in Brocade Prints, the Carriage of the Virtuous Woman, known as the Marriage series" (c.1769) by Suzuki Harunobu

programme.title: The World Is Filled with Words: A Deaf Photographer's Journey
programme.desc: What are "words"? What does it mean to communicate? Deaf photographer Saito Harumichi seeks answers as he raises his hearing children and prepares an exhibition reflecting his quest for connection.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE

programme.title: Towards a Nature Positive Future: A Mission for National Parks
programme.desc: 90 years after the creation of Japan's national parks, we introduce the charms of the Setonaikai, Aso and other natural wonders, which are key to the Nature Positive strategy for the planet.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Darwin's Amazing Animals
programme.sub-title: Precious Neighbors — Japanese Pond Turtle, Japan
programme.desc: Japanese pond turtles live in the rivers and ponds of Japan. Recently, however, the species has been designated as near threatened due to environmental changes and the presence of invasive species. However, during a six-month tracking project, researchers found that they actually take full advantage of the rich Satoyama landscape areas. They feed on insects in rice paddies, fruits in the woods and tomatoes in the fields. The team also discovered that they even lay eggs in agricultural greenhouses. This episode looks through the eyes of these amazing creatures to reveal their surprising way of life.

programme.title: Time-lapse Journey
programme.desc: The Amakusa region has over 120 islands and is home to one of the places where a unique form of Christianity developed. See Amakusa's historic sights and natural beauty through time-lapse photography.

programme.title: Let's Enjoy MATH with Barky the Dog
programme.sub-title: Can You Count Them? ―Numbers Larger Than 10―
programme.desc: Numbler comes and distracts a boy trying to count his cows at a farm. Barky helps with the counting by grouping the cows into units of 10.

programme.title: TAKE TECH
programme.desc: Talk into a microphone and your voice comes out from a speaker, loud and clear. Find out how the mic, speaker and amplifier work together to make sounds louder.

programme.desc: In Japan, sweet potatoes are often baked or turned into sweets. But they can also be used to generate electricity or protect from heat. We introduce the diverse ways in which they are used and sold.

programme.desc: Two herb farmers' cats live next door to each other. Their relationship is tense due to a past fight. At Takeya Kannonji Temple, the chief priest lives with four cats that always stay by his side.

programme.desc: New student "u" is from a different country. "i" invites "u" to play by signaling with her hand, but that upsets "u." "u" misunderstood because gestures can mean different things in different countries.

programme.title: Easy Japanese for Work
programme.sub-title: #43 Determining what is worrying a client
programme.desc: Today: determining what is worrying a client. Lin Zhipeng, from China, works at a real estate firm. He began studying Japanese after becoming interested in anime, and came to Japan five years ago. At his job, he's involved with property inspections and assisting clients. He had a bad experience once when a customer asked to change to a Japanese agent. He wants to regain his confidence. In a roleplay challenge, he must determine what is worrying his client.

programme.title: Zero Waste Life
programme.desc: Lumber that's too short or too narrow can be hard to sell. Offcuts are usually discarded or end up as woodchips. But Tanaka Ryosuke and Miyachi Yoh use them for furniture. Not big enough for large panels, multiple boards must be glued together, leading to uneven coloring. The answer, to dye the furniture with indigo, transforming each piece into a unified whole. This clever idea and their love of wood itself gives their work an inner beauty that's attracting real interest.

programme.title: Little Charo
programme.desc: Little Charo is an animation series about a Japanese dog who got lost in NY. "I want to see my owner again!" Charo starts his adventure back home.

programme.title: Japanology Plus mini
programme.desc: In Japan, sweet potatoes are often baked or turned into sweets. But they can also be used to generate electricity or protect from heat. We introduce the diverse ways in which they are used and sold.

programme.title: A Cat's-Eye View of Japan
programme.desc: Two herb farmers' cats live next door to each other. Their relationship is tense due to a past fight. At Takeya Kannonji Temple, the chief priest lives with four cats that always stay by his side.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE

programme.title: On the Wings
programme.desc: Pilot's Choice: Tokyo's dazzling night views! A close-up on the ground crew's "Airport Magic" for on-time flights.

programme.title: Core Kyoto mini
programme.sub-title: An Artistic Lineage: Nurturing a painting tradition
programme.desc: Kyoto City University of Arts, founded in 1880, has produced leading painters in the art world. Its policy emphasizes Shasei: painting from life through intensive observation.

programme.title: Easy Japanese for Work
programme.sub-title: #43 Determining what is worrying a client
programme.desc: Today: determining what is worrying a client. Lin Zhipeng, from China, works at a real estate firm. He began studying Japanese after becoming interested in anime, and came to Japan five years ago. At his job, he's involved with property inspections and assisting clients. He had a bad experience once when a customer asked to change to a Japanese agent. He wants to regain his confidence. In a roleplay challenge, he must determine what is worrying his client.

programme.title: Zero Waste Life
programme.desc: Lumber that's too short or too narrow can be hard to sell. Offcuts are usually discarded or end up as woodchips. But Tanaka Ryosuke and Miyachi Yoh use them for furniture. Not big enough for large panels, multiple boards must be glued together, leading to uneven coloring. The answer, to dye the furniture with indigo, transforming each piece into a unified whole. This clever idea and their love of wood itself gives their work an inner beauty that's attracting real interest.

programme.title: YONEZAWA: A Gift from Melted Snow
programme.sub-title: YONEZAWA: A Gift from Melted Snow
programme.desc: As snow melts in Yonezawa, it provides water used for growing rice. Beautiful time-lapse images show how a 400-year-old brewery turns this rice into sake, using human expertise instead of machines.

programme.title: Darwin's Amazing Animals
programme.sub-title: Precious Neighbors — Japanese Pond Turtle, Japan
programme.desc: Japanese pond turtles live in the rivers and ponds of Japan. Recently, however, the species has been designated as near threatened due to environmental changes and the presence of invasive species. However, during a six-month tracking project, researchers found that they actually take full advantage of the rich Satoyama landscape areas. They feed on insects in rice paddies, fruits in the woods and tomatoes in the fields. The team also discovered that they even lay eggs in agricultural greenhouses. This episode looks through the eyes of these amazing creatures to reveal their surprising way of life.

programme.title: Time-lapse Journey
programme.desc: The Amakusa region has over 120 islands and is home to one of the places where a unique form of Christianity developed. See Amakusa's historic sights and natural beauty through time-lapse photography.

programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: MATSURI: The Heartbeat of Japan
programme.desc: On New Year's Eve, performers dress as terrifying monsters called namahage. They barge into people's homes, condemning laziness and frightening children. But this good-natured tradition strengthens family and community bonds. In Tayazawa, a small village in Akita Prefecture, the practice came to an end several years ago, but was recently restarted by an enthusiastic group of locals. They made costumes and succeeded in reviving a custom at risk of slipping away.

programme.sub-title: Dental Breakthroughs To Save Your Smile
programme.desc: Periodontal disease-causing bacteria are hard to eliminate. A device developed in Japan uses hydrogen peroxide and blue light. Work is also underway to regenerate periodontal tissue using stem cells.

programme.title: Journeys in Japan
programme.desc: The San'in Kaigan Geopark Trail is a 230-kilometer-long course connecting the Sea of Japan coastline along Tottori, Hyogo, and Kyoto prefectures, which were designated as a UNESCO Global Geopark. Canadian actor Kyle Card dives into the dynamic landscapes—veritable museums of topography and geology where traces of Earth from 30 million years ago remain—and the way of life in old fishing villages.

programme.title: DEEPER LOOK
programme.sub-title: Yoshiki: The Journey to Global Icon. Yoshiki, Cultural Icon.
programme.desc: Yoshiki, the Japanese icon, reflects on how he bridges Japanese and US cultures through his music, fashion, and film.

programme.title: Dig More Japan
programme.desc: The youth of Japan give their all to school activities and their dreams for the future.We dig a little deeper. The segments featured in this episode are available in full online at NHK WORLD-JAPAN ON DEMAND. *Please note that due to the available terms of the video, some of the links may be expired.

programme.title: Dining with the Chef Mini
programme.desc: Learn about easy, delicious, and healthy cooking with Chef Rika in five minutes! Featured recipe: Rika's Chakin Sushi.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE

programme.title: Dining with the Chef
programme.sub-title: Authentic Japanese Cooking: Udon in Egg-drop Soup
programme.desc: Learn about Japanese home cooking with Master Chef Saito, based on traditional Japanese cooking techniques! Featured recipes: (1) Udon in Egg-drop Soup (2) Salmon with Tofu Wasabi Dressing.

programme.title: NEWSROOM TOKYO
programme.desc: NEWSROOM TOKYO dives deeper into the day's news with insight and analysis, from the perspective of Japan and the rest of Asia. We put a spotlight on what you need to know to understand the issues.

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: Wastewater Research for Public Health: Kitajima Masaaki / Project Professor, Research Center for Water Environment Technology, The University of Tokyo
programme.desc: In 2020, Kitajima Masaaki published the world's first paper on how the spread of COVID-19 could be tracked by monitoring wastewater. He talks about making an impact on infectious disease control.

programme.title: Herbal Symphony
programme.desc: Autumn in Japan's oldest private medicinal herb garden in Uda, Nara Prefecture. As the plants bear fruit, the garden's custodians protect the seeds, ensuring that they live on for future generations.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.sub-title: A Night of Fashion and Fireworks
programme.desc: For a time during the Edo period, fireworks lit up the skies practically every night in the summer. It was a chance for women to dress up and let loose ... and grab the attention of male suitors. *"Women Watching Fireworks at Sumida River" (1795-96) by Kitagawa Utamaro

programme.title: Today's Close-Up
programme.sub-title: Inside the 'Black Box' Hospital: Hidden Crisis in Japan's Psychiatric Care
programme.desc: The former director of Michinoku Kinen Hospital in Aomori Prefecture and his doctor brother were arrested for trying to cover up a killing inside the facility in February. The hospital takes in many patients who other hospitals wouldn't accept. The case exposed a string of irregularities, such as death certificates that were signed by doctors reportedly impaired by dementia. Against the backdrop of an aging society, we look into why the hospital found itself in a situation where family wishes were disregarded, and patients' human rights were routinely ignored. Guest: Takagi Shunsuke (Psychiatrist)

programme.title: Document 72 Hours
programme.sub-title: Praying for Blue Skies at Tokyo's Weather Shrine
programme.desc: A shrine in Tokyo is dedicated to a deity believed to control the weather. For three days in fall, a season of fickle weather in Japan, we asked people why they wanted divine help for sunny skies.

programme.title: Science View
programme.sub-title: A Quantum Search for Optimal Solutions

programme.desc: The majority of Niger, in Africa, is occupied by the Sahara, and desertification is a major problem. Oyama Shuichi introduces his method of increasing vegetation using household waste.

programme.title: Herbal Symphony

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.desc: Edo was a city of waterways. The Yoroi Ferry transported people across the Nihonbashi River, one of its main commercial arteries. programme.title: Trails to Oishii Tokyo

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: The World Heritage Sites in Japan
programme.sub-title: A Spirit of Harmony : Buddhist Monuments in the Horyu-ji Area
programme.desc: From natural landscapes to historic architecture representing centuries of cultural development, Japan's World Heritage sites offer a wide range of glimpses into history and the beauty of nature.

programme.title: YONEZAWA: A Gift from Melted Snow
programme.sub-title: YONEZAWA: A Gift from Melted Snow
programme.desc: As snow melts in Yonezawa, it provides water used for growing rice. Beautiful time-lapse images show how a 400-year-old brewery turns this rice into sake, using human expertise instead of machines.

programme.title: Where We Call Home
programme.sub-title: Conveying the Pride of Caring for Cattle
programme.desc: We meet Afghani Gulhabib Habiby who takes care of cattle on a farm in Kanoya, Kagoshima Prefecture, and Nepalese Rukesh Raj Giri who runs a produce store in Tokyo.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: MATSURI: The Heartbeat of Japan
programme.desc: On New Year's Eve, performers dress as terrifying monsters called namahage. They barge into people's homes, condemning laziness and frightening children. But this good-natured tradition strengthens family and community bonds. In Tayazawa, a small village in Akita Prefecture, the practice came to an end several years ago, but was recently restarted by an enthusiastic group of locals. They made costumes and succeeded in reviving a custom at risk of slipping away.

programme.title: JAPAN DELISH
programme.desc: Japanese festival favorite, yakisoba! Noodles cooked in a special sauce. Enjoy local yakisoba from all over Japan!

programme.title: Nun's Cookbook
programme.desc: The temple chefs make butterbur miso. Just boil butterbur shoots, then grind with sugar, mirin and white miso. The taste is slightly bitter, but perfect for early spring.

programme.title: Hometown Stories
programme.sub-title: Survivors: Capturing Life After the Atomic Bomb
programme.desc: Tsuchida Hiromi has photographed the everyday lives of people who survived the atomic bombing of Hiroshima, decades apart. Now, 80 years after the bombing, what fresh realities will he capture?

programme.title: Satoyama Kitchen Fall #8
programme.desc: At the Satoyama Kitchen guesthouse in Hida Takayama, chef Nobuko, her cameraman husband Makoto and their cat Tama take us on a tasty journey of local cuisine served with a side of seasonal scenery.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Nun's Seasonal Calendar
programme.desc: In this episode, we learn about ritto and shosetsu, two dates of early winter. The nuns teach us how to make seasonal pickles and dumplings.

programme.title: The Beauty of Japanese Swords
programme.desc: Japanese swords, admired since ancient times for their beauty, are amazing works of art. This time, Odachi, a giant sword that showcases a swordsmith's astonishing expertise.

programme.title: Time-lapse Journey
programme.desc: Iwate Prefecture is home to many historic sites which were made to represent Buddhist paradise. Chuson-ji Temple in Hiraizumi, a World Heritage Site, is home to the golden Konjikido hall which offers a prayer for peace. The garden in Motsu-ji Temple was made as a depiction of paradise and has been also registered as a World Heritage Site. Catch a glimpse of eternity through time-lapse photography.

programme.title: Activate Your Japanese!
programme.desc: Drama "Xuan Tackles Japan!" Xuan struggles with the planning for the hotel's autumn campaign, and Rei gives her some advice that she should broaden her horizons. But Xuan is baffled. What should she do to broaden her horizons? How can she be able to understand his advice? "Onomatopoeia" -Share Feelings- Wakuwaku "Welcome to My Japan!" focuses on the life of Enkhuyanga ENKHBAYAR from Mongolia, who works at a company that produces industrial chemicals in Shiga Prefecture!

programme.title: Culture Crossroads
programme.sub-title: The Comedy Club Where I Belong
programme.desc: In a stand-up comedy club in Tokyo, people from all over the world try out bilingual jokes. For James from Australia, comedy has changed his life, helping him find a place where he feels he belongs.

programme.title: HELLO! NHK WORLD-JAPAN
programme.sub-title: A London Screening of Grand Sumo Legends
programme.desc: A sumo tournament is being held in London for the first time in 34 years. At a screening of Grand Sumo Legends, Wajima: The Golden Left, attendees can learn about NHK WORLD-JAPAN's useful services.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: CINEMATIC JOURNEY
programme.desc: Kyle Card hikes along the 1,000km trail following the Pacific Coast in northern Japan, where he discovers local lifestyles, stunning nature, traces of the area's 2011 disaster, and resilient people.

programme.title: The Masterpieces of Ukiyo-e producer Tsutaju
programme.desc: This miniseries presents the masterpieces of Tsutaju, a brilliant ukiyo-e producer of the Edo period. This episode takes a close look at artist Utamaro's iconic "Woman with a Glass Noisemaker."

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: Adapting Anime Costumes for Live-Action: Nakahara Sachiko / Stylist and Costume Designer
programme.desc: Nakahara Sachiko translates the looks of popular Japanese anime and manga characters into costumes for live-action adaptations. She talks about making an impact on the global stage.

programme.title: Hit the Road
programme.desc: Take a drive in Fukushima Prefecture! 13 years since the disaster, see its rejuvenated community and daily life. Visit the rest stop emblematic of this resilience and sense the locals' unyielding spirit.

programme.title: JAPAN FROM ABOVE: UP CLOSE / Co-production between NHK, Gedeon Programmes, ZDF Arte, and Voyage
programme.desc: In this episode, we meet a man who runs a salmon hatchery in the Shonai plains of Yamagata Prefecture.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.desc: A group of anglers stand in a fast-moving, undulating river at the foot of a rugged cliff. They use "drifting mosquito hooks" to fish for a summer delicacy that was a favorite of the Edo townspeople. *"Fly-fishing" from the series "One Thousand Pictures of the Ocean" (c.1833) by Katsushika Hokusai

programme.title: Today's Close-Up
programme.sub-title: AI Robot Revolution: Impact on Caregiving
programme.desc: From serving as conversation partners for the elderly to helping people walk again, AI robots are revolutionizing nursing care in Japan. The industry is facing a severe labor shortage, but the robots are helping to ease the burden on overtaxed caregivers and doctors. One expert says this is just the first step in the wider introduction of AI robots to our daily lives. As software capabilities catch up with existing hardware, it could be a matter of time before we see general-purpose humanoid robots at shops, offices, and even in our homes. We bring you the latest on the progress of AI robots. Guest: Furuta Takayuki (General Manager, Future Robotics Technology Center, Chiba Institute of Technology)

programme.title: Seasoning the Seasons
programme.desc: This program visits places across Japan to introduce the charms of their local daily life and festivals fostered by the nation's long history.

programme.title: MATSURI: The Heartbeat of Japan
programme.desc: In Kurume, Fukuoka Prefecture, the first week of the new year culminates in Oniyo: the night of the oni, or demon. Six giant torches, measuring 13 meters and weighing 1.2 tons, are moved around a shrine precinct. They create a shadow in which the oni can emerge. One torch is taken to the river, where the oni conducts a ritual that cleanses people of their troubles. This matsuri also recounts a 1,600-year-old story about a local hero defeating an outlaw—who goes on to become the oni.

programme.title: Journeys in Japan
programme.desc: The San'in Kaigan Geopark Trail is a 230-kilometer-long course connecting the Sea of Japan coastline along Tottori, Hyogo, and Kyoto prefectures, which were designated as a UNESCO Global Geopark. Canadian actor Kyle Card dives into the dynamic landscapes—veritable museums of topography and geology where traces of Earth from 30 million years ago remain—and the way of life in old fishing villages.

programme.title: Today's Close-Up
programme.sub-title: Inside the 'Black Box' Hospital: Hidden Crisis in Japan's Psychiatric Care
programme.desc: The former director of Michinoku Kinen Hospital in Aomori Prefecture and his doctor brother were arrested for trying to cover up a killing inside the facility in February. The hospital takes in many patients who other hospitals wouldn't accept. The case exposed a string of irregularities, such as death certificates that were signed by doctors reportedly impaired by dementia. Against the backdrop of an aging society, we look into why the hospital found itself in a situation where family wishes were disregarded, and patients' human rights were routinely ignored. Guest: Takagi Shunsuke (Psychiatrist)

programme.title: Darwin's Amazing Animals
programme.sub-title: Precious Neighbors — Japanese Pond Turtle, Japan
programme.desc: Japanese pond turtles live in the rivers and ponds of Japan. Recently, however, the species has been designated as near threatened due to environmental changes and the presence of invasive species. However, during a six-month tracking project, researchers found that they actually take full advantage of the rich Satoyama landscape areas. They feed on insects in rice paddies, fruits in the woods and tomatoes in the fields. The team also discovered that they even lay eggs in agricultural greenhouses. This episode looks through the eyes of these amazing creatures to reveal their surprising way of life.
